description: From Middle English abjuren, from Latin abiūrō (“deny upon oath”) (possibly via Middle French abjurer), formed from ab (“from, away from”) + iūro (“swear or take an oath”), from iūs (“law, right, duty”).

verbs.description: abjure (third-person singular simple present abjures, present participle abjuring, simple past and past participle abjured)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To renounce upon oath; to forswear; to disavow. [First attested around 1350 to 1470.]
examples: adore then the terrestrial influences, and abjure Mahomet.

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete, historical) To cause one to renounce or recant. [First attested around 1350 to 1470.]
(transitive) To reject with solemnity; to abandon forever; to repudiate; to disclaim. [First attested around 1350 to 1470.]
(transitive) To abstain from; to avoid; to shun.
examples: Except during the season in town, she spends her year in golfing, either at St Magnus or Pau, for, like all good Americans, she has long since abjured her native soil.
